title: Paul's Defense of the Gospel
shortSummary: In Galatians 2, Paul recounts his visit to Jerusalem to confirm the gospel he preaches to the Gentiles and confronts Peter over hypocrisy. This chapter highlights the centrality of justification by faith in Christ rather than by works of the law, emphasizing Christian liberty and unity in the gospel.
timeline: c. AD 48-49 - Paul's visit to Jerusalem fourteen years after his conversion

keyCharacters.name: Paul
keyCharacters.description: The apostle who defends the gospel of grace and recounts his authoritative mission to the Gentiles.

keyCharacters.name: Peter (Cephas)
keyCharacters.description: A leading apostle representing the Jewish believers, who is confronted by Paul for withdrawing from Gentile fellowship.

keyCharacters.name: Barnabas
keyCharacters.description: Paul's companion on the Jerusalem visit and fellow worker in the gospel ministry.

keyCharacters.name: James
keyCharacters.description: The brother of Jesus and a pillar of the Jerusalem church who extends fellowship to Paul and Barnabas.

keyCharacters.name: Titus
keyCharacters.description: A Greek believer who accompanied Paul and was not compelled to be circumcised, illustrating freedom from the law.

definitions.definition: The act by which God declares a sinner righteous through faith in Jesus Christ, apart from works of the law.
A physical sign of the Old Testament covenant with Israel, which some falsely insisted was necessary for Gentile believers.
Individuals who secretly sought to impose legalistic requirements on Gentile Christians to undermine the gospel of grace.
God's unmerited favor toward sinners, which is the basis for salvation and Christian living.

outline.heading: Paul’s Jerusalem Visit and Gospel Confirmation
outline.description: Paul describes his trip to Jerusalem with Barnabas and Titus to confirm the gospel he preaches to the Gentiles, receiving recognition and fellowship from the church leaders.

outline.heading: Paul Confronts Peter Over Hypocrisy
outline.description: Paul openly rebukes Peter for withdrawing from Gentile believers under pressure from Jewish Christians, exposing inconsistency that threatened gospel truth.

outline.heading: Theological Explanation of Justification by Faith
outline.description: Paul explains that justification comes through faith in Christ, not by works of the law, emphasizing his union with Christ and the futility of relying on the law for righteousness.

application: Stand firm in the gospel of grace and do not allow legalism to undermine your faith in Christ alone for salvation.
Practice integrity and consistency in your Christian walk, avoiding hypocrisy especially in how you relate to others in the body of Christ.
Remember that true Christian life is lived by faith in Jesus, relying on His righteousness rather than your own efforts.
Be willing to confront error lovingly and boldly when the truth of the gospel is at stake.

keyVerses.text: Knowing that a man is not justified by the works of the law, but by the faith of Jesus Christ, even we have believed in Jesus Christ, that we might be justified by the faith of Christ, and not by the works of the law: for by the works of the law shall no flesh be justified.
keyVerses.significance: This verse clearly states the foundational Christian doctrine that justification is by faith in Christ alone, not by law-keeping.

keyVerses.text: I am crucified with Christ: nevertheless I live; yet not I, but Christ liveth in me: and the life which I now live in the flesh I live by the faith of the Son of God, who loved me, and gave himself for me.
keyVerses.significance: Paul expresses the believer’s union with Christ in His death and resurrection, highlighting the transformative power of faith.

keyVerses.text: But when Peter was come to Antioch, I withstood him to the face, because he was to be blamed.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows Paul’s courage in confronting even prominent leaders when they compromise the gospel.
